items.title: TikTok inks deal with American investors to keep app operating in U.S.
British Columbians deal with aftermath of heavy rain while bracing for more
items.summary_auto: While the Fraser Valley has seen devastating flooding over the last 10 days, other parts of the province are also dealing with the aftermath of multiple atmospheric river storm systems.

items.title: Alberta hikes referendum petition fee from $500 to $25K
items.summary_auto: Alberta Premier Danielle Smith's government is hiking the cost to apply for a citizen-initiated referendum by 5,000 per cent, saying it's about making sure applicants are serious.

items.title: Integrity commissioner to investigate Ontario labour minister's handling of controversial training fund
items.summary_auto: Ontario's ethics watchdog says it will investigate whether the province's labour minister contravened any laws in his handling of a controversial training fund.

items.title: B.C. grocery store to pay $750K after washroom videos ended up on porn site
items.summary_auto: A Vancouver Island grocery store has agreed to pay $750,000 to settle a voyeurism class-action lawsuit brought by women who were secretly filmed in the bathroom by a former employee who uploaded the images to a Russian porn site.

items.title: Former NASCAR driver Greg Biffle among 7 dead in N.C. plane crash
items.summary_auto: A business jet crashed Thursday while trying to return to a North Carolina airport shortly after takeoff, killing all seven people aboard, including retired NASCAR driver Greg Biffle and his family, authorities said.

items.title: CBSA employees involved in 259 founded misconduct cases last year: report
items.summary_auto: From interfering in immigration processing to associating with a known drug trafficker, Canada Border Services Agency employees were embroiled in hundreds of misconduct cases last year, according to a new report.

items.title: Investigators probe links between Brown University shooting, MIT professor killing
items.summary_auto: Authorities are investigating a connection between last weekend's mass shooting at Brown University and the killing of an MIT professor two days later.

items.title: Wildfires, drought and storms top Canada's top weather stories of 2025
items.summary_auto: Environment and Climate Change Canada's top 10 weather stories of the year include the second-worst wildfire season on record and droughts that stretched across the country.

items.title: Former Vancouver Canuck Willie Mitchell denies sexual assault allegations in court documents
items.summary_auto: Former Vancouver Canuck defenceman Willie Mitchell has denied he sexually assaulted a 26-year-old woman at his Tofino, B.C., condo in 2022.

items.title: Trump-picked board votes to add his name to Kennedy Center
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump's handpicked board voted Thursday to rename Washington's leading performing arts center as the Trump-Kennedy Center, the White House said, in a move that was quickly denounced as a "disgrace" by the Democratic leader of the House, who is on the board.

items.title: Trump executive order could change marijuana classification in U.S.
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump signed an executive order Thursday that could reclassify marijuana as a less dangerous drug and open new avenues for medical research — a major shift in federal drug policy that inches closer to what many states have done.

items.title: Romanian court sentences U.S. rapper Wiz Khalifa to 9 months for drug possession
items.summary_auto: American rapper Wiz Khalifa was sentenced by a court in Romania on Thursday to nine months in jail for drug possession, more than a year after he took part in a music festival in the Eastern European country.

items.title: Supply management 'not on the table,' says Carney as U.S. bent on changing dairy rules
items.summary_auto: Prime Minister Mark Carney reaffirmed he’ll protect Canada’s supply management system, as the United States signalled it's ready to fight over this country's dairy rules at the negotiating table.

items.title: Christian Dubé steps down as Quebec health minister, leaves CAQ party
items.summary_auto: Quebec Health Minister Christian Dubé is stepping down. Dubé cited difficult negotiations with the unions representing doctors in Quebec as one of the reasons behind his resignation.

items.title: Organized crime group busted in theft of over $1M in drugstore face creams, razors in Ontario and Quebec
items.summary_auto: Police say they disrupted a "highly organized" retail theft syndicate in Ontario and Quebec with the arrest of 21 people, ranging in age from 15 to 75. Two suspects were picked up in B.C.

items.title: B.C. Mountie ordered to resign or be fired after vulgar group chats
items.summary_auto: Coquitlam Const. Ian Solven, convicted of discreditable conduct for making sexist comments in group chats, has been ordered to resign within 14 days, or he will be fired. The fate of the two other officers will be handed down in the new year.

items.title: N.L.'s medical officer of health urges vaccinations as flu season begins early
items.summary_auto: Newfoundland and Labrador’s chief medical officer of health is urging residents to get a flu shot ahead of the holidays.

items.title: Is there a wrong way to gain a parliamentary majority?
items.summary_auto: Pierre Poilievre says Mark Carney is "trying to manipulate his way through backroom deals" to get a majority. Mark Carney says he's "comfortable commanding the confidence of the House of Commons." These duelling interpretations raise a useful question of civics.

items.title: At least 319 people 'summarily executed' by Sudan's RSF in April, UN group says
items.summary_auto: Over 1,000 civilians were killed when a Sudanese paramilitary group took over a famine-stricken displacement camp in Sudan's Darfur in April, including about a third who were summarily executed, according to a report released by the UN's Human Rights Office on Thursday.

items.title: Canada cuts 3 from world junior camp, roster at allowable 25 players
items.summary_auto: Three players have been cut from Canada's roster as the team continues preparations for the world junior hockey championship.

items.title: Who will be on the Canadian women’s Olympic hockey team?
items.summary_auto: Twenty-three players will represent Canada in women's hockey at Milano-Cortina Olympics. The Canadians open defence of their gold medal on Feb. 5 against Finland. Here’s a projected list of who is likely to be selected to the team, which will be announced on Jan. 15

items.title: Zelenskyy urges EU leaders to agree on handing over Russian assets
items.summary_auto: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy urged EU leaders to reach a deal at a fraught summit on Thursday, where the group was trying to overcome differences on whether to use frozen Russian assets to finance Ukraine's war effort.

items.title: How Venezuelan crude could shake things up for Canadian producers
items.summary_auto: Venezuela's bitumen-heavy oil is virtually identical to Canada's and the South American country has the largest proven reserves in the world. But Venezuelan oil has essentially disappeared from world markets over the past 20 years. U.S. President Donald Trump's threats to invade Venezuela have opened up the prospect that it could one day return, with huge implications for Canada.

items.title: Crown withdraws murder charge against Toronto man who spent 23 years in prison
items.summary_auto: The Court of Appeal for Ontario last month ordered a new trial for Timothy Rees, who had been convicted of second-degree murder in 1990 for the killing of a 10-year-old girl.

items.title: Thieves dressed as Santa and his elves steal $3K worth of goods from Montreal grocery store
items.summary_auto: Several people dressed as Santa and a group of masked elves were filmed at a grocery store in Montreal on Monday night filling up carts with food. An activist group calling themselves Robins des ruelles or Robins of the Alleys claimed responsibility for the heist. The group says the stolen food was redistributed in the community.

items.title: Air Transat's parent company reports $12.5M loss in latest quarter
items.summary_auto: The parent company of Air Transat reported a loss of $12.5 million in its latest quarter, compared with a profit of $41.2 million in the same quarter last year.

items.title: New plaques on Trump's 'Presidential Walk of Fame' insult, mock former U.S. presidents
items.summary_auto: President Donald Trump has affixed partisan plaques to the portraits of all U.S. commanders in chief, himself included, on his Presidential Walk of Fame at the White House, describing Joe Biden as "sleepy," Barack Obama as "divisive" and Ronald Reagan as a fan of a young Trump.

items.title: How Saskatchewan hurdler Savannah Sutherland put herself in mix for prestigious NCAA award
items.summary_auto: Olympic hurdler Savannah Sutherland of Borden, Sask., could hear her name announced Thursday night as the first Canadian female recipient of The Bowerman, U.S. collegiate track and field's highest individual honour.

items.title: Canada Life denied amputee coverage to RCMP officer injured in the line of duty. Advocates say he’s not alone
items.summary_auto: When retired RCMP constable Jason Hydamacka heard the news that the insurance money for his amputated leg was coming, he sat in his truck and cried. Originally denied the coverage, Canada Life reversed its decision after CBC News reached out to it.

items.title: U.S. announces $11.1B weapons package for Taiwan, angering China
items.summary_auto: The United States on Wednesday approved $11.1 billion US in arms sales to Taiwan, the largest ever U.S. weapons package for the island which is under increasing military pressure from China.

items.title: Toronto man charged with defrauding 28 investors of $6.6M
items.summary_auto: A Toronto man has been charged for allegedly defrauding 28 investors of $6.6 million they provided to trade in foreign exchange following an Ontario Securities Commission investigation.

items.title: Trump hasn't threatened ripping up North American trade deal in private talks, Carney says
items.summary_auto: Prime Minister Mark Carney says U.S. President Donald Trump hasn't given him any indication that he's willing to walk away from the North American free trade deal that was struck during his first term at the White House.

items.title: The best Canadian books of 2025
items.summary_auto: Still trying to find that perfect book for someone on your list this holiday season? You're in luck. Here are CBC Books' No. 1 picks for the top Canadian fiction, nonfiction, poetry, comics and kids books of the year.

items.title: 10 years since MAID in Quebec, woman who fought to expand it hopes Canada catches up
items.summary_auto: Diagnosed with Alzheimer’s in her late 30s, Sandra Demontigny pushed Quebec to allow advanced requests for MAID. While Quebec has become a leader internationally for the practice over the past decade, she hopes others keep up the fight in the rest of Canada.

items.title: Cease-and-desist letter served to Ring of Fire mining company by Neskantaga First Nation
items.summary_auto: Neskantaga First Nation is calling on PTX Metals Inc. to halt all mining exploration activities in the Ring of Fire region, which the remote Ojibway community in northwestern Ontario says is on its traditional territory. The First Nation has served the company a cease and desist letter.

items.title: U.S. Supreme Court decision on Trump's tariffs could bring more trade uncertainty to Canada
items.summary_auto: Canada is yet again on the precipice of economic uncertainty as a result of U.S. President Donald Trump’s global trade war. This time it's connected to an upcoming decision by the U.S. Supreme Court.

items.title: China, Russia pulling ahead of NATO in Arctic drone capabilities: report
items.summary_auto: NATO countries, including Canada, are falling behind Russia and China in the development of Arctic-capable drones — uncrewed aerial and land vehicles that are ideal for surveillance.

items.title: Signs of trouble in the U.S. economy: Where are all the jobs?
items.summary_auto: Donald Trump promised his economic policies would lead to a golden age and a boom in manufacturing jobs. The latest economic data show job growth is slowing and manufacturing jobs are being lost.

items.title: Delays in gynecological surgeries putting women’s health — and lives — at risk, doctors warn
items.summary_auto: Long wait times for gynecological surgeries are putting many Canadian women at risk, doctors say. Surgical wait times vary across the country, but a 2020 study found that a gynecologist consultation alone can take up to four and a half months on average.
